node.name: continue - optional trailing block in a while or foreach
node.description:
Actually a flow control statement rather than a function. If there is a [perlfunc:continue|continue] BLOCK attached to a BLOCK (typically in a while or foreach), it is always executed just before the conditional is about to be evaluated again, just like the third part of a for loop in C. Thus it can be used to increment a loop variable, even when the loop has been continued via the [perlfunc:next|next] statement (which is similar to the C [perlfunc:continue|continue] statement).

[perlfunc:last|last], [perlfunc:next|next], or [perlfunc:redo|redo] may appear within a [perlfunc:continue|continue] block. [perlfunc:last|last] and [perlfunc:redo|redo] will behave as if they had been executed within the main block. So will [perlfunc:next|next], but since it will execute a [perlfunc:continue|continue] block, it may be more entertaining. 

    while (EXPR) {
        ### redo always comes here
        do_something;
    } continue {
        ### next always comes here
        do_something_else;
        # then back the top to re-check EXPR
    }
    ### last always comes here

Omitting the [perlfunc:continue|continue] section is semantically equivalent to using an empty one, logically enough. In that case, [perlfunc:next|next] goes directly back to check the condition at the top of the loop.
